content:
• Friday, December 14, 2018
  • YRIV

    STOR, RES and KDMN among after hour movers

    • Top Gainers: YRIV +12.1%. RES +7.4%. ENVA +4.5%. TLK +4.4%. SURF +3.6%.
    • Top Losers: KDMN -2.8%. STOR -2.6%. PLYA -2.4%. SUM -1.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:44 PM | 3 Comments
  • CPRX

    Catalyst Pharma +3.4% as director buys 20,000 shares

    • Catalyst Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:CPRX) is up 3.4% postmarket, after the disclosure that director Charles O'Keeffe bought 20,000 shares today.
    • O'Keeffe got the shares at an average price of $2.50, for an outlay of about $50,000.
    • Following the transaction, his holdings sit at 543,376 shares.
    • Shares fell 4.9% during the regular session, on heavy volume today.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM | 6 Comments
  • SUPN

    FDA OKs Supernus Pharma's Oxtellar XR as monotherapy for partial-onset seizures

    • The FDA approves Supernus Pharmaceuticals' (NASDAQ:SUPN) marketing application to use Oxtellar XR (oxcarbazepine) extended-release tablets as monotherapy to treat partial-onset seizures in patients at least six years old.
    • Previously, the epilepsy med was approved as adjunctive treatment for partial-onset seizures in patients at least six years old.
    • Market launch for the new indication will commence next quarter.
    • Shares are up a fraction after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM | 4 Comments
  • XOM

    Crude oil settles sharply lower after weak China data, stronger dollar

    • Crude oil prices tumbled to wipe out the week's prior gains, weighed by a big drop in equities that followed weaker than expected data on China's economic growth as well as a stronger dollar; U.S. WTI settled -2.6% to $51.20/bbl, Brent -2.1% to $60.12/bbl.
    • "For the time being until the OPEC cuts start kicking in, the market is oversupplied in the short term," says Mitsubishi oil risk manager Tony Nunan, adding "if China is slowing down, that's definitely a concern."
    • A stronger U.S. dollar plus volatile equity markets have weighed down crude, says Giovanni Staunovo, commodities analyst at UBS Wealth Management, but overall "I would think oil prices are in a position of stabilizing around this level," aided by planned production curbs from OPEC and Russia.
    • Also, January natural gas futures settled -7.2% to $3.827/MMBtu, suffering its largest weekly drop (-14.7%) for a front month since January 2016.
    • The "outlook for warmer-than-normal to normal weather through the end of the month" weighed on prices, says James Williams of WTRG Economics. "That, coupled with record high production of gas are the main reasons, despite very low levels of gas in storage for this time of year."
    • Oil and gas names are broadly lower: XOM -2.3%, CVX -2.2%, COP -2.5%, CHK -9.5%, RRC -8.8%, SWN -8.1%, APA -3.7%, DVN -3.9%, APC -3.4%, CXO -5%, EOG -3.1%, MRO -4.2%, NBL -4.3%, HES -2.3%, SLB -5.1%, HAL -3.3%, BHGE -2.7%, CVRR -10%, SM -9.5%, RIG -7%, ESV -8%, NE -6.8%.
    • ETFs: USO, UNG, XLE, OIL, UGAZ, UWT, DGAZ, UCO, VDE, XOP, DWT, ERX, OIH, SCO, BNO, BOIL, GASL, FCG, DBO, ERY, DIG, BGR, GUSH, DTO, FENY, USL, IYE, DUG, KOLD, DRIP, IEO, FIF, UNL, GASX, DNO, NDP, PXE, OLO, RYE, PXJ, SZO, CRAK, DCNG, FXN, OLEM, WTIU, DDG, OILK, NANR, OILX, WTID, USOI, USOU, GAZB, USOD, FTXN, JHME, ERYY, ERGF, OILD, OILU, USAI
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 131 Comments
  • BT

    UK telecoms face price-transparency push from regulators

    • Some UK-facing telecoms have moved today after the country's regulators look to force price transparency measures that could crimp earnings the companies see from unaware consumers.
    • Regulator Ofcom plans to force all electronic communications services -- Internet, pay TV and phone -- to alert customers to their best available prices as contracts end, and each year after that.
    • "We want people to be able to take advantage of the wide choice of communication services available and shop around with confidence, so that at the end of their fixed commitment period they can get the best deals for their needs," Ofcom says. "This could mean taking up a new deal with their current provider, or switching to a new supplier."
    • At incumbent telecom BT, there could be a 40% difference between new and historical prices, Barclays notes -- which creates an annual earnings exposure of up to £500M. (h/t Bloomberg)
    • BT is down 0.8% in U.S. trading. Other affected companies: VOD; LBTYA -2.3%; TEF -1.3%; OTCPK:TKTCY; OTCPK:CKHUY +1%; CMCSA -1.3% (via Sky).
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 1 Comment
  • INTC

    Thoma Bravo could buy McAfee for over $4.2B; SYMC -4%

    • Intel (INTC -0.7%) and TPG are in early talks to sell McAfee to private equity firm Thoma Bravo for "significantly" more than $4.2B, according to CNBC sources.
    • Intel bought McAfee for $7.6B in 2010.
    • TPG acquired a stake in McAfee in 2006 that valued the cybersecurity company at $4.2B. TPG later brought Thoma Bravo in as a minority investor.
    • Deal talks could change or fall apart. Sources say that if Thoma Bravo does buy McAfee, it will back away from a Symantec (NASDAQ:SYMC) purchase.
    • SYMC is down 4.1% to $21.55.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:48 PM | 12 Comments
  • RUN

    Sunrun -10% on FBI investigation report

    • Sunrun (NASDAQ:RUN) plunges 10.7% on a Seeking Alpha article detailing a previously undisclosed FBI and Justice Department investigation for fraud that runs parallel to the SEC investigation.
    • The information came to light through a Freedom of Information Act request.
    • Read Investor Gator's full rundown here.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:26 PM | 2 Comments
  • PSX

    Phillips 66 unveils $2.3B capital spending program for 2019

    • Phillips 66 (PSX -2.4%) announces a $2.3B capex budget for 2019 and reiterates its long-term objective to reinvest 60% of cash flow into the business and return 40% to shareholders through dividends and buybacks.
    • PSX says it plans $1.6B in capex at its Midstream segment, including $601M million for Phillips 66 Partners (PSXP +0.7%), and reflects expected joint venture-level financing to fund part of the Gray Oak Pipeline construction.
    • PSX also plans $923M of capital spending in its refining business and $161M in the Marketing and Specialties segment.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM | 6 Comments
  • TI

    Telecom Italia receives request from Vivendi for shareholder meeting

    • Telecom Italia (TI -2.2%) has confirmed that it's gotten a formal request from Vivendi (VIVHY -1.6%), its largest shareholder, to convene a shareholders' meeting as part of Vivendi's wrestling match with Elliott Management.
    • Vivendi's proposed agenda includes revoking five directors (Fulvio Conti, Alfredo Altavilla, Massimo Ferrari, Dante Roscini and Paola Giannotti de Ponti) and appointing its chosen replacements (Franco Bernabè, Rob van der Valk, Flavia Mazzarella, Gabriele Galateri di Genola and Francesco Vatalaro).
    • Vivendi "asked that the agenda of the Shareholders’ Meeting includes a vote on the revocation of five Board members from the Elliott list who showed a substantial lack of independence and disrespect for the most basic and fundamental corporate governance rules, negatively affecting the organization and image of Telecom Italia," it says.
    • It's also asking for new financial auditors.
    • Vivendi lost control of the company to Elliott last May in a board shift.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:06 PM
  • LRAD

    Microcaps mostly among tech movers

    • Gainers: LRAD Corporation (NASDAQ:LRAD) +13%. Fusion Connect (NASDAQ:FSNN) +11%. Materialise NV (NASDAQ:MTLS) +7%. Aware (NASDAQ:AWRE) +6%. Resonant (NASDAQ:RESN) +6%.
    • Losers: One Stop Systems (NASDAQ:OSS) -17%. Intermolecular (NASDAQ:IMI) -13%. Shopify (NYSE:SHOP) -12%. CSP (NASDAQ:CSPI) -12%. nLIGHT (NASDAQ:LASR) -11%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM
  • GOLD

    WSJ: U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office investigates Acacia Mining

    • The U.K.’s Serious Fraud Office is investigating Barrick Gold (ABX -2.8%) subsidiary Acacia Mining (OTCPK:ABGLF) over allegations of corruption in Tanzania, WSJ reports.
    • The British probe into Acacia focuses around accusations that employees of the company, which was called African Barrick until 2014, bribed Tanzanian government officials and consultants, according to the report.
    • Acacia also is being investigated by Tanzanian officials over corruption allegations, and the interest of U.K. law enforcement marks a new level of scrutiny over the company and another headache for ABX.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM | 8 Comments
  • SCG

    SCANA +6% as state regulators say they will support Dominion takeover

    • SCANA (SCG +6.6%) soars to a 52-week high after a majority of South Carolina regulators indicate they will vote to approve the company's acquisition by Dominion Energy (D +1.4%).
    • At least five of the seven members of the state's Public Service Commission said ahead of this afternoon's vote that they would support the deal to buy the parent company of South Carolina Electric & Gas.
    • The PSC also will decide how much to cut rates for 737K SCE&G customers who already have paid $2B-plus related to the abandoned V.C. Summer nuclear reactor projected.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:37 PM | 30 Comments
  • JNJ

    J&J: Reuters story 'false'

    • "The Reuters article is one-sided, false, and inflammatory," says the company. "Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ -9.4%) baby powder is safe and asbestos-free."
    • J&J notes studies of more than 100K people show talc doesn't cause cancer or asbestos-related disease.
    • Source: Press Release
    • Previously: Johnson & Johnson down 4% on reports of prior knowledge of asbestos in baby powder (Dec. 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:30 PM | 176 Comments
  • YRCW

    YRC Worldwide -20% after DoJ alleges 'systematic overcharging' of shipments

    • YRC Worldwide (YRCW -20.5%) sinks to a 52-week low after the U.S. Department of Justice files a lawsuit against some of the company's units alleging the freight companies "systematically overcharged" the federal government for freight carrier services and made false statements to hide their misconduct.
    • The lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court in Buffalo alleges that for more than seven years the subsidiaries defrauded the Defense Department "by millions of dollars for shipments that were actually lighter, and thus cheaper, than the weights for which the defendants charged the government."
    • YRCW says the government's claims are "totally without merit."
    • Other freight companies also trade lower: JBHT -2.9%, WERN -2.2%, ODFL -1.2%, ARCB -1.2%, KNX -0.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:25 PM | 10 Comments
  • TMUS

    Reuters: T-Mobile/Sprint expect CFIUS clearance, if they drop Huawei

    • T-Mobile (TMUS -1.2%) and Sprint (S -1.3%) now expect their proposed merger to get U.S. security clearance as soon as next week after their parent companies said they'd consider dropping use of equipment from China's Huawei, Reuters reports.
    • The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States is reviewing the deal between the two companies, owned respectively by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY -0.4%) and Japan's SoftBank (SFTBY -6.6%).
    • And the U.S. is applying pressure to stop using equipment from Huawei over concerns about "back doors" that would enable espionage by China.
    • SoftBank plans to replace Huawei gear with equipment from Ericsson (ERIC -1.5%) and Nokia (NOK -1.1%), Nikkei reported.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:16 PM | 25 Comments
  • AAPL

    D.A. Davidson cuts Apple target, says pullback overdone

    • D.A. Davidson maintains a Buy rating on Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) but cuts the price target from $290 to $280.
    • Analyst Tom Forte cites near-term projections on lower than expected iPhone sales and reiterates that higher ASPs on the new iPhones could result in an upside to the firm's forecast.
    • Forte says that the recent pullback was overdone and that the lower near-term performance is already priced into shares.
    • Apple shares are down 2.4% to $166.79.
    • Previously: Noted analyst cuts iPhone estimates (Dec. 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM | 77 Comments
  • WPM

    Wheaton Precious Metals and Valhi among Energy/Materials gainers; Comstock Resources and New Concept Energy among losers

    • Gainers: Wheaton Precious Metals (NYSE:WPM) +15%. Valhi (NYSE:VHI) +7%. Tantech (NASDAQ:TANH) +6%. CONSOL Coal Resources (NYSE:CCR) +4%.
    • Losers: Comstock Resources (NYSE:CRK) -15%. New Concept Energy (NYSEMKT:GBR) -14%. CVR Refining (NYSE:CVRR) -13%. Mexco Energy (NYSEMKT:MXC) -12%. Legacy Reserves (NASDAQ:LGCY) -11%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:00 PM
  • ADBE

    Analysts trim Adobe targets, express Marketo concerns

    • Pivotal Research maintains a Hold rating on Adobe (NASDAQ:ADBE) and lowers the target from $254 to $252 after earnings.
    • Analyst Brian Wieser: "Revised 2019 guidance on first glance also had negative characteristics relative to our prior estimates and those of consensus, but on further review and with additional information from the company conveyed during the call, long-term trends appear to be on track."
    • More analyst comments: Guggenheim's Ken Wong says that Adobe's "overall Marketo dilution likely came in higher than investors anticipated."
    • Marketo contributed $21M in revenue but would've taken $0.07 off of the non-GAAP EPS if included.
    • Adobe shares are down 6% to $233.13.
    • Previously: Adobe reports mixed Q4, updates FY guidance (Dec. 13)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:54 PM | 5 Comments
  • CHACU

    Chardan Healthcare Acquisition debuts today

    • Blank Check company Chardan Capital Acquisition (CHACU) should begin trading today. It is offering 7M Units at $10 per Unit, each consisting of one ordinary share and one five-year warrant to purchase 1/2 of an ordinary share at $11.50.
    • Underwriter representative Chardan Capital Markets has an option to purchase up to an additional 1.05M Units.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:01 PM
  • CIFS

    China Internet Nationwide Financial Services the only financial gainer whereas; Maiden Holdings leads losers

    • Gainers: China Internet Nationwide Financial Services (NASDAQ:CIFS) +14%.
    • Losers: Maiden Holdings (NASDAQ:MHLD) -9%. PPDAI Group (NYSE:PPDF) -9%. Hexindai (NASDAQ:HX) -8%. Wheeler Real Estate Investment Trust (NASDAQ:WHLR) -6%. American Finance Trust (NASDAQ:AFIN) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:55 PM | 1 Comment
  • ALQA

    Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: Alliqua BioMedical (NASDAQ:ALQA) +40%. Belmond (NYSE:BEL) +40%. Civitas Solutions (NYSE:CIVI) +20%. XPO Logistics (NYSEMKT:XPO) +14%. Wheaton Precious Metals (NYSE:WPM) +14%. China Internet Nationwide Financial (NASDAQ:CIFS) +14%. Fusion Connect (NASDAQ:FSNN) +13%. iKang Healthcare Group (NASDAQ:KANG) +11%. Innovate Biopharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:INNT) +11%. The Dixie Group (NASDAQ:DXYN) +10%.
    • Losers: Draper Oakwood Technology (NASDAQ:DOTA) -41%. Good Times Restaurants (NASDAQ:GTIM) -21%. Aileron Therapeutics (NASDAQ:ALRN) -21%. Idera Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:IDRA) -19%. DAVIDsTEA (NASDAQ:DTEA) -17%. GEE Group (NYSEMKT:JOB) -16%. Francesca's Holdings (NASDAQ:FRAN) -13%. Applied DNA Sciences (NASDAQ:APDN) -13%. Cocrystal Pharma (NASDAQ:COCP) -13%. YRC Worldwide (NASDAQ:YRCW) -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:42 PM

  • Healthcare leads markets lower as J&J plunges 10%

    • Johnson & Johnson is being stung by reports it knew for years about contaminants in its baby powder. That's helping the Healthcare SPDR (NYSEARCA:XLV) to a 3% decline vs the S&P 500's 1.2% fall.
    • The Nasdaq is also off 1.2%, with Amazon, Apple, and Cisco all sporting 2%+ drops.
    • ETFs: XLV, VHT, IYH, HQH, CURE, THQ, FHLC, FXH, RXL, RYH, SICK, LNGR, RXD, BTEC, JHMH, HCRF
     
     
     
     
    | 12:36 PM | 17 Comments
  • JNJ

    Sell-siders defend Johnson & Johnson

    • On cue, sell-side analysts are quickly discounting the revelations in the Reuters article that Johnson & Johnson (JNJ -9.8%) knew about the potential presence of asbestos in its baby powder for many years.
    • Wells Fargo: "Stock oversold on the story."
    • Susquehanna: "Reuters article not news."
    • JPMorgan: "Selloff an over-reaction."
    • Citigroup: "Company completely refutes Reuters article."
    • Jefferies: "10% decline overdone."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:30 PM | 67 Comments
  • SEE

    Sealed Air +4% after unveiling restructuring plan

    • Sealed Air (SEE +4.4%) surges after announcing its Reinvent SEE strategy, including a new restructuring program aimed at achieving $215M-$235M in annualized savings by year-end 2021.
    • The company says Reinvest SEE aims to drive growth with leading brands and packaging innovations for Fresh Food and e-Commerce and increase operating leverage target above 40%/year beginning in 2019.
    • SEE estimates total annualized savings from restructuring during the three year period of $240M-$260M, including $60M-$80M in savings during 2019.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM
  • BHC

    J&J weighing on big biopharma players

    • The broad market's bearish notwithstanding, members of Big Biopharma are under water pressured by the news that Johnson & Johnson may have known about contaminants in its baby powder for decades. The company is mired in thousands of product liability lawsuits that will take years to adjudicate.
    • Selected tickers: (BHC +0.4%)(OTCQX:RHHBY -2%)(ABBV -1.9%)(AGN -1.1%)(AZN -0.6%)(BMY -2%)(GSK -1.1%)(JNJ -9.9%)(LLY -2.4%)(MRK -1.9%)(NVO -0.5%)(NVS -1.1%)(PKE -0.1%)(SHPG -0.5%)(TEVA -1.3%)(AMGN -2.5%)(BIIB -1%)(GILD -1.8%)(CELG -1.7%)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:20 PM | 57 Comments
  • YETI

    YETI Holdings leads consumer gainers;DAVIDsTEA and Libbey among losers

    • Gainers: YETI Holdings (NYSE:YETI) +6%. Ardagh Group (NYSE:ARD) +5%. Dogness (International) (NASDAQ:DOGZ) +5%.
    • Losers: DAVIDsTEA (NASDAQ:DTEA) -17%. Arcimoto (NASDAQ:FUV) -13%. Libbey (NYSEMKT:LBY) -6%. Electrameccanica Vehicles (NASDAQ:SOLO) -6%. Farmmi (NASDAQ:FAMI) -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:06 PM
  • CSTM

    Copper drops amid weak China economic data; Freeport McMoran -4%

    • Copper prices tumble alongside stocks and other risk assets, as disappointing economic data from China and Europe add to mounting concerns that weakening growth at the end of this year will carry over into a sharper slowdown next year.
    • Comex copper for March delivery -1.2% to $2.733/lb. and are now down ~17% from their June four-year highs on fears that slower global economic growth will slow demand for materials used heavily in construction and manufacturing.
    • Elsewhere in base metals: aluminum -0.6% to $1,920/metric ton, zinc -1.4% to $2,529.50, tin -0.2% to $19,365, nickel -0.3% to $10,815, lead -0.7% at $1,935.50.
    • Among major industrial metals stocks: CSTM -6.6%, FCX -4.4%, BHP -2.7%, CLF -2.4%, RIO -2.1%, TECK -0.7%, AA -0.3%, SCCO -0.2%.
    • ETFs: XLB, OTCPK:JJCTF, BCX, PEO, VAW, COPX, DBB, UYM, IYM, JJN, CPER, GNR, HAP, FMAT, MXI, SMN-OLD, GUNR, BOM, FXZ, BDD, RTM, BOS, RJZ, GRES, SBM, BDG-OLD, UBM, JHMA, JJUB
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM | 15 Comments
  • CLVS

    European advisory group backs expanded use for Clovis' Rubraca

    • The European Medicines Agency's advisory group CHMP has adopted a positive opinion recommending approval to use Clovis Oncology's (CLVS -7.5%) Rubraca (rucaparib) as monotherapy for  the maintenance treatment of adult patients with platinum-sensitive relapsed high-grade epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer who are in response (complete or partial) to platinum-based chemotherapy.
    • Rubraca is currently approved in the EU for adult patients with platinum sensitive, relapsed or progressive, BRCA mutated (germline and/or somatic), high-grade epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer, who have been treated with two or more prior lines of platinum based chemotherapy, and who are unable to tolerate further platinum based chemotherapy.
    • A final decision from the European Commission usually takes ~60 days.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:56 AM | 1 Comment
  • LITB

    LightInTheBox +7% post Q3 results

    • LightInTheBox (LITB +7.7%) reported Q3 revenue decrease of 42.3% Y/Y to $44.5M. Revenue by Product sales $42.91M (-40.7% Y/Y) and Services & others $1.59M (-66% Y/Y).
    • Total orders of product sales were 0.8M, compared 1.7M a year ago.
    • Product sales: Europe was $21.2M (-44.8% Y/Y), North America was $10.9M (-38.2% Y/Y), Gulf Cooperation Council countries was $2.6M, and other countries were $8.2M.
    • Q3 Gross profit declined by 2,110 bps to 15.1%.
    • Q3 Loss from operations was $18.1M, compared to $2M a year ago.
    • Company has cash and cash equivalents and restricted cash of $38.3M, as of September 2018.
    • Previously: LightInTheBox reports Q3 results (Dec. 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:46 AM
  • BAC

    Financials lose the least in market decline

    • The financial sector loses the least (-0.4%) on Friday heading into midday, with some financial names actually making gains.
    • Bank of America (BAC +1.3%) gains after Morgan Stanley analyst Betsy Graseck defends the stock.
    • U.S-based megabanks waver between rising and falling for much of the morning. Now, they're down: Citigroup (C -0.2%), Wells Fargo (WFC -0.3%), JPMorgan (JPM -0.2%).
    • U.S. regional banks, though, are mixed: Comerica (CMA +0.3%), PNC Financial (PNC +0.1%), and Axos Financial (AX +0.1%) lead, with  CIT Group (CIT -1%), U.S. Bancorp (USB -1.1%) and Regions Financial (RF -0.8%) lagging.
    • Auto lenders -- Ally Financial (ALLY +0.8%), Santander Consumer USA (SC +1.7%), and Credit Acceptance (CACC +1.6%) -- move up strongly.
    • Online brokers Charles Schwab (SCHW +0.4%), E*Trade (ETFC +0.9%),  and TD Ameritrade (AMTD) also gain.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:42 AM | 21 Comments
  • SBGL

    AMCU union says it remains on strike at Sibanye-Stillwater

    • Sibanye-Stillwater (SBGL -2.6%) is lower after the president of South Africa’s AMCU union said its members remain on strike, disputing the miner’s position that the action is now illegal.
    • The union says its members should not to report to work, "as they are still in a protected strike until their demands have been met"; the company says the strike is now unprotected according to South African labor laws, and employees who fail to return to work would be subject to disciplinary measures.
    • AMCU, which represents ~43% of SBGL’s gold workforce in South Africa, called the strike in mid-November after discussions over wages broke down.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:35 AM | 24 Comments
  • MDB

    Needham raises MongoDB target on roadmap

    • Needham maintains a Buy rating on MongoDB (NASDAQ:MDB) and raises the price target by $6 to $97.
    • Analyst Jack Andrews cites a meeting and call with management that left the firm believing that "MDB's product roadmap has a multi-year feature advantage in meeting the requirements of modern applications over most competitors."
    • MDB is up 1% to $90.48.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:30 AM | 2 Comments
  • NRZ

    New Residential bounces as KBW advises buying the dip

    • It's been a rough fall for New Residential (NYSE:NRZ), with shares down about 20% since Labor Day. This makes for an attractive entry point, says KBW bull Bose George, noting the stock now changes hands at just 92% of trailing book value.
    • George says the particularly sharp drop of the past two weeks is mostly thanks to reset expectations on interest rates - lower rates negatively impact the value of NRZ's portfolio of mortgage servicing rights. George, however, figures the MSR mark will be rather modest, perhaps 1-2%.
    • There's also NRZ's clean-up call rights - they're not represented in book value, but will flow through to earnings. George figures these rights alone are worth $1.75 per share.
    • George reiterates his Outperform rating and $19 price target.
    • Shares +1.8% today to $15.85.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:27 AM | 91 Comments
  • JBHT

    Credit Suisse defends J.B. Hunt Transport Services

    • Credit Suisse thinks the announcement by J.B. Hunt Transport Services (JBHT -2.8%) of a charge related to BNSF arbitration (SEC Form 8-K) could be a negative signal for margins in 2019, although the firm remain positive on the set-up for the upcoming year.
    • "Despite a ~20% pullback in the stock since the beginning of Q4, we continue to be bullish on JBHT given the ’19 EPS power and the improving return profile," writes analyst Allison Landry.
    • "Specifically, we recognize 1) the pipeline for DCS growth with 30+ new customers, 2) potential pricing power in ’19 as JBHT pulls the lever on price rather than volumes, and 3) Marketplace 360, which supports efficiency and asset utilization," she adds.
    • Credit Suisse keeps an Outperform rating on JBHT and price target of $148 (+50% upside potential).
     
     
     
     
    | 11:25 AM
  • JBL

    RBC lowers Jabil target ahead of earnings

    • RBC Capital maintains a Sector Perform rating on Jabil (NYSE:JBL) and lowers the target from $33 to $29.
    • Jabil will report earnings on December 18. Analysts expect $0.88 EPS and $6.1B in revenue.
    • Jabil shares are down 0.5% to $22.14.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:24 AM
  • SPLK

    Splunk, Anaplan move on Hedgeye mentions

    • Splunk (NASDAQ:SPLK) shares are down 1% after headlines that Hedgeye recommends short Splunk, long Anaplan (NYSE:PLAN), which is up 1.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:19 AM | 1 Comment
  • MNI

    McClatchy +6.5% after report its Tribune Publishing bid is rejected

    • Tribune Publishing (TPCO +0.5%) shares are sanguine, but McClatchy (NYSEMKT:MNI) is up 6.5%, after a Bloomberg report that Tribune Publishing rejected McClatchy's $16.50/share buyout offer.
    • Tribune is talking to other buyers rather than going for the fully financed cash-and-stock offer, according to the report ($15/share in cash).

  • JNJ

    Johnson & Johnson down 4% on reports of prior knowledge of asbestos in baby powder

    • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ -3.7%) is down out the gate this morning on reports that it knew for decades that its baby powder could be contaminated with asbestos.
    • The earliest mention on possible contaminants was in the late 1950s from a consulting lab, according to Reuters who has examined thousands of pages of company documents as well as deposition and trial testimony. It found that, from 1971 to the early 2000s, company executives and others (including doctors and lawyers) fretted over the problem and how to address it while avoiding disclosure.
    • The company is working through almost 12K product liability lawsuits related to alleged consumer harm from long-term use of its baby powder and continues to deny prior knowledge of any contamination. It declined to comment further on the Reuters piece.

    Idera Pharma down 11% premarket on updated mid-stage tilsotolimod data

    • Idera Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:IDRA) is down 11% premarket on light volume following its release of updated results from the Phase 2 ILLUMINATE-204 study evaluating tilsotolimod plus Bristol-Myers Squibb's (NYSE:BMY) Yervoy (ipilimumab) in advanced melanoma patients who failed to respond to PD-1 inhibitor therapy [Merck's (NYSE:MRK) Keytruda (pembrolizumab)].
    • 34 patients were evaluable for efficacy and 37 for safety. The overall response rate (ORR) was 32% (n=11/34), including two complete responders. Using RECIST v1.1 criteria, the ORR was 29%. The disease control rate (responders + stable cancer) was 76% (n=26/34).
    • No new safety signals were observed.
    • In October, the company reported an ORR of 39% (n=8/21 which is actually 38%) which was consistent with the results reported in June.
